animalOfTheDay.name: water buffalo
facts: Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.
Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.

calendar.name: viper
facts: Horned vipers in deserts move via sidewinding to avoid hot sand.
Gaboon vipers have longest fangs (2 inches) and highest venom yield.
Their hinged fangs fold against the roof of mouth when not striking.
Vipers have heat-sensing pits detecting temperature changes as small as 0.003°C.

calendar.name: vulture
facts: Vultures are scavenging birds of prey.
They are known for their bald heads, which help keep them clean while feeding.
Vultures play a crucial role in ecosystems by cleaning up carcasses.
They have an excellent sense of smell.

calendar.name: wallaby
facts: Rock wallabies scale cliffs using textured soles and tail balancing.
Wallabies cool by licking forearms; saliva evaporation lowers blood temperature.
They practice embryonic diapause; pausing development until environmental conditions improve.
Wallabies hop efficiently – energy use doesn't increase with speed.

calendar.name: walrus
facts: They are social animals and live in large herds.
Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.
They are found in Arctic waters.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.

calendar.name: warthog
facts: Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.
Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.

calendar.name: wasp
facts: Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.

calendar.name: water buffalo
facts: Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.
Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.

randomAnimals.name: indri
facts: They feed mainly on leaves, flowers, and fruits, and their diet is highly specialized.
Unlike many lemurs, indri have a short tail and an upright body posture.
They are known for their unique, loud songs, which are used for communication between groups and territorial marking.
Indri are the largest living lemurs, inhabiting the eastern rainforests of Madagascar.

randomAnimals.name: bee
facts: A single bee will only produce 1/12th of a teaspoon of honey in her lifetime.
They communicate through a complex 'waggle dance' to share location of flowers.
Bees have five eyes and can see ultraviolet patterns on flowers invisible to humans.
They maintain their hive temperature at exactly 95°F year-round.

randomAnimals.name: tuna
facts: They are warm-blooded, unlike most fish, which helps them swim in cold waters.
Tuna can migrate across entire oceans, traveling thousands of miles.
They have a unique circulatory system that conserves heat in their muscles.
Tuna are among the fastest fish, reaching speeds up to 47 mph.
